Event.name: Cause_motion
Event.definition:
<def-root>An <fen>Agent</fen> causes a <fen>Theme</fen> to move from a <fen>Source</fen>, along a <fen>Path</fen>, to a <fen>Goal</fen>. Different members of the frame emphasize the trajectory to different degrees, and a given instance of the frame will usually leave some of the <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> and/or <fen>Goal</fen> implicit. The completion of motion is not required (unlike the Placing frame, see below), although individual sentences annotated with this frame may emphasize the <fen>Goal</fen>. <ex></ex> This frame is very broad and contains several different kinds of words that refer to causing motion. Some words in this frame do not emphasize the <fen>Manner</fen>/<fen>Means</fen> of causing the motion (transfer.v, move.v). For many of the others (cast.v, throw.v, chuck.v, etc.), the <fen>Agent</fen> has control of the <fen>Theme</fen> only at the <fen>Source</fen> of motion, and does not experience overall motion. For others (e.g. drag.v, push.v, shove.v, etc.) the <fen>Agent</fen> has control of the <fen>Theme</fen> throughout the motion; for these words, the <fen>Theme</fen> is resistant to motion due to some friction with the surface along which they move.
<ex><fex name="Agent">She</fex> <t>threw</t> <fex name="Theme">her shoes</fex> <fex name="Goal">into the dryer</fex> .</ex> <ex><fex name="Agent">The mechanic</fex> <t>dragged</t> <fex name="Theme">the jack</fex> <fex name="Source">out from under the car</fex> .</ex> <ex><fex name="Agent">We</fex> will <t>move</t> <fex name="Theme">the sofa</fex> <fex name="Source">out of the room</fex> <fex name="Path">through the french doors</fex>, <fex name="Path">down the stairs</fex>, and <fex name="Goal">onto the sidewalk</fex> .</ex> <ex></ex> <ex></ex>
This frame is used in a very large number of productive metaphors, not all of which can be outlined here. The most salient types include causing an entity, construed as a <fen>Theme</fen>, to change state from an initial state (<fen>Source</fen>) via an intermediate state (<fen>Path</fen>) to a final state (<fen>Goal</fen>): <ex><fex name="Theme">Hillary</fex> was <t>catapulted</t> <fex name="Goal">to stardom</fex> and his life has never been the same since . <fex name="Agent">CNI</fex></ex> <ex><fex name="Theme">She</fex> felt as though <t>flung</t> <fex name="Source">from health</fex> <fex name="Goal">to illness</fex> and <fex name="Goal">back</fex> <fex name="Time">by the day , by the hour</fex> .</ex> <ex><fex name="Time">Once our parents are dead</fex> , <fex name="Theme">we</fex> are <t>catapulted</t> <fex name="Goal">into becoming the older generation ourselves</fex> . <fex name="Cause">CNI</fex></ex> <ex><fex name="Theme">Croquet</fex> was <t>pushed</t> <fex name="Source">out</fex> <fex name="Cause">by tennis</fex> .</ex> <ex></ex>
A particularly divergent subtype casts changing someone's intentions as changing their location: <ex><fex name="Agent">Democrats</fex><t>forced</t> <fex name="Theme">the Senate</fex> <fex name="Goal">into a rare closed door session</fex> .</ex> <ex><fex name="Agent">He</fex> <t>nudged</t> <fex name="Theme">Mrs Thatcher</fex> <fex name="Goal">towards acceptance of a unified Germany</fex> .</ex> <ex></ex>
Another subtype is specifically about causing a change in quantity (the <fen>Theme</fen>) through some sequence of values (<fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen>, and <fen>Goal</fen>): <ex>Bonus payments would be handed out for <t>pushing</t> <fex name="Path">up</fex> <fex name="Theme">voting levels</fex> <fex name="Agent">CNI</fex> .</ex> <ex></ex>
Another type, with many subtypes, involves causing an action or state (construed as a <fen>Theme</fen>) to have an effect on another person or location or conceptual domain. In such cases, the<fen>Goal</fen> is used for the final affected domain, and <fen>Source</fen> for initial affected domain, <fen>Path</fen> for an intermediate affected domain, and <fen>Distance</fen> for degree of difference between original application of the action and final: <ex><fex name="Agent">Jake</fex> had been <t>hurling</t> <fex name="Theme">these same insults</fex> <fex name="Goal">at her</fex> <fex name="Time">now</fex> <fex name="Duration">for years</fex></ex> <ex><fex name="Agent">One</fex> can not <t>press</t> <fex name="Theme">this argument</fex> <fex name="Distance">too far</fex> .</ex> <ex><fex name="Agent">She</fex> <t>shoved</t> <fex name="Theme">the thought</fex> <fex name="Goal">to the very back of her mind</fex> .</ex> <ex><fex name="Agent">She</fex> <t>flung</t> <fex name="Goal">him</fex> <fex name="Theme">a savage little smile</fex> .</ex> All of the foregoing metaphorical uses are annotated in this frame and marked "Metaphor", since they seem to be semantically motivated and not lexically idiosyncratic. <ex></ex> <ex></ex>
This frame contrasts with the following frames which talk about an <fen>Agent</fen> changing a <fen>Theme</fen>'s position with respect to a landmark (either <fen>Source</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>): <ex></ex>
In Placing, the figure (<fen>Theme</fen>) is profiled as the object, and ends up on the ground (<fen>Goal</fen>). The focus is on the final stage of motion, in which the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up at the <fen>Goal</fen>, and usually stably remains there. <ex>Joyce <t>placed</t> <fex name="Theme">the flowers</fex> <fex name="Goal">onto the bed</fex>.</ex> <ex></ex>
In Filling, the ground (<fen>Goal</fen>) is profiled as the object, and the figure (<fen>Theme</fen>) ends up on the ground (<fen>Goal</fen>). <ex>John <t>filled</t> <fex name="Goal">the box</fex> <fex name="Theme">with old toys</fex>.</ex> <ex></ex>
In Removing, the figure (<fen>Theme</fen>) is profiled, and is removed from the ground (<fen>Source</fen>). <ex>Jennifer <t>removed</t> <fex name="Theme">the flowers</fex> <fex name="Source">from the bed</fex>.</ex> <ex></ex>
In Emptying, the ground (<fen>Source</fen>) is profiled and the figure (<fen>Theme</fen>) is removed from it. <ex>Jason <t>emptied</t> <fex name="Source">the box</fex> <fex name="Theme">of the old toys</fex> .</ex> <ex></ex>
Words of this frame also differ from the words of the Bringing frame in that they are more general: either the <fen>Agent</fen> has a momentary interaction with the <fen>Theme</fen> that causes its motion, unlike the continuous causation of Bringing, or the <fen>Agent</fen> continuously acts on the <fen>Theme</fen>, but there is no supporting object that helps with the motion like the Carrier of the Bringing frame. </def-root>

Arg.name: Agent
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Agent</fen> is the one whose action causes the motion of a <fen>Theme</fen>. The <fen>Agent</fen> is generally realized as the External Argument.
<ex><fex name="Agent">Pat</fex> <t>threw</t> the china at the wall.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Theme
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The FE <fen>Theme</fen> is generally an NP Object.
<ex>Pat <t>threw</t> <fex name="Theme">the china</fex> at the wall.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Source
Arg.definition: <def-root>The FE <fen>Source</fen> is the starting point of motion. <ex>Pat dragged the box <fex name="Source">out of the cupboard</fex>.</ex></def-root >

Arg.name: Path
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The FE <fen>Path</fen> is any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor <fen>Goal</fen>.
<ex>I <t>pushed</t> the trolley <fex name="Path">along the street</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Goal
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The FE <fen>Goal</fen> is the point at which the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.
<ex>Kim <t>threw</t> the cat <fex name="Goal">into the garden</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Distance
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The FE <fen>Distance</fen> is any expression characterizing the extent of motion of the <fen>Theme</fen>.
<ex>Pat <t>threw</t> the Javelin <fex name="Distance">50 meters</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Area
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The FE <fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular or not to consist of a single, linear path. Locative setting adjuncts may also be assigned this frame element.
<ex>Kim <t>pushed</t> the lawnmower <fex name="Area">around the garden</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Depictive
Arg.definition: <def-root>The state of a participant during the action <ex>We <t>pushed</t> the cart around, <fex name="Depictive">gleeful</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Degree
Arg.definition: <def-root>Degree to which event occurs</def-root>

Arg.name: Means
Arg.definition: <def-root>The FE <fen>Means</fen> indicates the action that is taken that results in the motion of the <fen>Theme</fen> </def-root>

Arg.name: Manner
Arg.definition: <def-root>The FE <fen>Manner</fen> is any expression which describes a property of the motion of the <fen>Theme</fen> which is not directly related to the trajectory of motion. Descriptions of steadiness, grace, and other things count as <fen>Manner</fen> expressions. </def-root>

Arg.name: Subregion
Arg.definition:
<def-root><fen>Subregion</fen> identifies the part of the <fen>Theme</fen> that makes contact with the resulting location. When <fen>Subregion</fen> is expressed, there usually is no <fen>Goal</fen> expressed.
<ex>The horse <t>pitched</t> the rider <fex name="Subregion">on his head</fex></ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Cause
Arg.definition:
<def-root><fen>Cause</fen> marks expressions that indicate some non-intentional, typically non-human, force that causes the <fen>Theme</fen> to be set in motion.
<ex><fex name="Cause">The storm</fex> <t>tossed</t> the sailor from the boat</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Instrument
Arg.definition:
<def-root>An entity saliently involved in the transmission of force from an <fen>Agent</fen> to a <fen>Theme</fen>. It may be the <fen>Agent</fen>'s bodypart, or some kind of device.
<ex>When passing a basketball, you should <t>throw</t> <fex name="Ins">with bath hands</fex>.</ex>
</def-root>

Arg.name: Place
Arg.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Place</fen> is the general area that provides a setting for a specific motion (with <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen>, or <fen>Goal</fen>).</def-root>

Arg.name: Time
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The time at which the motion of the <fen>Theme</fen> occurs.
<ex>We <t>shoved</t> half of the cargo overboard <fex name="Time">on the 29th</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Result
Arg.definition:
<def-root>A resultant state that the <fen>Theme</fen> is in at the end of its motion.
<ex>The fireman <t>dragged</t> the injured driver <fex name="Result">clear</fex></ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Handle
Arg.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Agent</fen>'s manipulation of the <fen>Theme</fen> may be further specified as being localized to some part of the <fen>Theme</fen>, a <fen>Handle</fen>. The <fen>Handle</fen> is usually expressed as a PP</def-root>

Arg.name: Initial_state
Arg.definition:
<def-root>A previous state that the <fen>Theme</fen> was in before the beginning of its motion.
<ex>Paul <t>pulled</t> Fran upright <fex name="Initial_state">from her sitting position</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Explanation
Arg.definition: <def-root>This FE denotes a proposition from which the main clause logically follows.</def-root>

Arg.name: Duration
Arg.definition: <def-root>The amount of time that the action requires.</def-root>

lexUnit.name: cast.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: send forth by throwing

lexUnit.name: catapult.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: hurl or launch with or as if with a catapult.

lexUnit.name: chuck.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: throw (something) carelessly or casually

lexUnit.name: drag.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: pull along forcefully, roughly, or with difficulty

lexUnit.name: fling.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: throw forcefully; hurl

lexUnit.name: hurl.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: throw or impel with great force

lexUnit.name: nudge.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: push gently or gradually

lexUnit.name: pitch.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: throw heavily or roughly

lexUnit.name: press.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: move or cause to move into a position of contact with something by exerting continuous physical force

lexUnit.name: push.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: exert force on (someone or something) in order to move them away from oneself

lexUnit.name: shove.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: push roughly

lexUnit.name: throw.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: propel with force through the air by a rapid movement of the arm and hand

lexUnit.name: thrust.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: push suddenly or violently in the specified direction

lexUnit.name: toss.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: throw lightly or casually

lexUnit.name: tug.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to pull (something) hard and suddenly, causing it to move

lexUnit.name: yank.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: pull with a jerk.

lexUnit.name: scoot.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: push or pull along a surface against resistance, generally causing it to move only a short distance.

lexUnit.name: draw.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: pull or move (something) in a specified direction.

lexUnit.name: run.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: cause to move while in light contact. [Generally of the fingers, tongue, or some entity manipulated by the hand.]

lexUnit.name: slide.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: cause to move along a surface, generally horizontally.

lexUnit.name: pull.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: exert force on so as to cause movement towards oneself or the origin of the force.

lexUnit.name: drive.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: propel or carry along by force in a specified direction.

lexUnit.name: move.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: cause (something) to move

lexUnit.name: force.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: push into a specified position using force.

lexUnit.name: haul.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: pull or drag with effort or force.

lexUnit.name: attract.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: draw or bring in by offering something of interest or advantage.

lexUnit.name: knock.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to push suddenly on something

lexUnit.name: punt.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to kick something as if it were a football

lexUnit.name: roll.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to rotate something on an axis

lexUnit.name: jerk.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: pull quickly and forcefully

lexUnit.name: propel.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: cause to move by means of some force

lexUnit.name: launch.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to hurl on abject

lexUnit.name: stick.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: thrust a typically sharp object in some direction or through something

lexUnit.name: transfer.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: the removal of a theme from a location or situation follwed by the relocation of that theme to a new location or situation.

lexUnit.name: hit.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to strike an object effectively causing it to move.

lexUnit.name: slam.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to throw forcefully

lexUnit.name: drop.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to let something fall downward

lexUnit.name: rake.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: move (something) using a rake.

lexUnit.name: impel.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to drive or cause to move onward; impart motion to

lexUnit.name: wrench.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to pull, jerk, or twist suddenly and forcibly

lexUnit.name: wrest.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to pull, jerk, or twist forcibly

lexUnit.name: lift.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to move or bring (something) upward from the ground or other support to a higher position
